newsitem.title: UK: Labour urge Clarke to come clean on UK finances.
newsitem.headline: Labour urge Clarke to come clean on UK finances.

text.p: Opposition Labour leader Tony Blair on Monday called on Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke to make it clear whether there was a "black hole" in Britain's public finances.

Blair was reacting to a press report that an independent think-tank had calculated that the next government would inherit a financial headache which would force it to raise taxes or cut public spending by up to 14 billion pounds ($22.96 billion).
"What this indicate yet again is a great black hole in the public finances," Blair told a news conference.
Blair said he had only read the report in the Independent newspaper of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research's findings.
But he said they showed that economics spokesman Gordon Brown was right to say that an incoming Labour government would need to work within tough cash spending limits.
"What I would like to know is what the Chancellor of the Exchequer says to this," Blair added. "Is this true or not? Does this deficit exist or not? We should be told."
Blair's news conference was called to launch a new document on Labour's policies towards small businesses.

He said Labour's determination to follow clear rules on public spending and introduce greater certainty and ie openness in decision-making about interest rates would help small firms to plan ahead. ($1=.6097 Pound)
